Effective conversion of heteroatomic model compounds in microalgae-based bio-oils to hydrocarbons over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst Junmei Liang a b Ranran Ding b Yulong Wu b ⁎ Yu Chen b Kejing Wu b Yongqiang Meng a Mingde Yang b Yaowu Wang b a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hebei University of Science and Technology, Shijiazhuang 050018, PR China College of Materials Science and Engineering Hebei University of Science and Technology Shijiazhuang 050018 PR China b Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, PR China Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Tsinghua University, Insitute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology, 205, PR China. Fax: +86 10 69771464. Graphical abstract A highly selective hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) and hydrodenitrogeneration (HDN) approach of heteroatomic model compounds in microalgae-based bio-oils to produce diesel-like hydrocarbons is provided over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst under a mild condition (≤200°C). The obtained results open a new possibility to upgrade microalgae-based bio-oils into high-grade transportation fuels at large. Hydrotreatment of heteroatomic model compounds in microalgae-based bio-oils into diesel-like hydrocarbons was carried out over carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-supported β-Mo2C catalyst with superior activity and selectivity under a mild condition (≤200°C). The results show that stearic acid and hexadecanamide can be completely converted into n-C15–C18 alkanes over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. The β-Mo2C/CNTs favors the pathway of hydrogenation–dehydration–hydrogenation to produce n-octadecane with an optimal yield of 91.24% at a lower temperature of 180°C during hydrotreating process of stearic acid. The recycle tests demonstrate that the β-Mo2C/CNTs exhibits excellent stability, and can be reused for seven times consecutively without reduction of catalytic stability. Based on the determined products, a brief reaction pathway is proposed. Therefore, a novel approach to produce diesel-like hydrocarbons via catalytic hydrotreatment of microalgae-based bio-oils over β-Mo2C/CNTs is introduced, which provides a basic research as well as technical parameters for its further industrialization. Keywords β-Mo2C/CNTs Diesel-like hydrocarbons Hydrotreatment Stearic acid Hexadecanamide 1 Introduction The increasing concerns over the depletion of non-renewable fossil resources and global climate change have attracted significant attention to explore renewable and environmental friendly sources of energy [1–5]. Of all the alternatives, biomass is regarded as the only material for the production of liquid fuel, which is considered to be one of the most sustainable alternatives to petroleum because of viable means for environmental and economic sustainability [6]. Among the biomass, microalgae is considered as one of the most promising energy sources for fuel production due to superior photosynthetic efficiency, higher growth rate, area-specific yield, and higher carbon dioxide utilization capabilities compared to terrestrial plants [7–10]. However, microalgae-based bio-oils obtained from thermochemical conversion contain appreciable quantities of oxygen and nitrogen heteroatoms, which result in undesirable property including corrosiveness, thermal instability, high viscosity and low heating value [11–14]. Therefore, it is desirable to remove the heteroatoms in the bio-oils to achieve high quality transport fuel. As reported in previous works, microalgae-based bio-oils contain a large amount of oxygen-containing compounds and nitrogen-containing compounds, especially C16–C18 long-chain fatty acids and amide compounds [13,15]. To this end, the necessary upgrading processes must be carried out via deoxygenation and denitrification prior to actual application. Among the upgrading technologies, catalytic hydrotreatment used for processing heavy crude petroleum and shale oils, is one of the most efficient approaches for removing heteroatoms in the microalgae-based bio-oils [16,17]. However, the conventional hydrotreating catalysts, such as sulfided NiMo and CoMo [18,19], may easily lead to the generation of sulfur compounds and sulfur leaching, which result in the deactivation of catalysts. As hydrotreating catalysts, supported noble metals (Pt, Pd, Rh, etc.,) also show superior activity and selectivity [20–25]. However, the high price greatly limits their large-scale practical applications [26]. Therefore, it is urgent to develop more sulfur-free and cost-effective catalyst with high activity and stability under mild conditions (≤200°C) for the upgrading of microalgae-based bio-oils. Transition-metal carbides, especially nanosized molybdenum carbides (Mo2C), have attracted considerable attention as promising alternative catalytic materials in hydrogen-involved reactions since the discovery of their “platinum-like” behavior, preferable resistance to poisoning of carbon monoxide and better anti-sintering characteristics [27–29]. Ren et al. [30] demonstrated that the Mo2C exhibited high hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity with propanal as a model compound. Han et al. [31] reported that carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-supported Mo2C could efficiently transform esters into diesel-like hydrocarbons in the presence of hydrogen. These papers clearly indicate the potential application of Mo2C as a selective catalyst for hydrotreating of oxygen-containing compounds. As mentioned above, long-chain fatty acids and amide compounds are main components of the microalgae-based bio-oil [13], and it is necessary to convert these heteroatomic compounds into chain hydrocarbons. However, few papers have reported the conversion of long-chain fatty acids and amide compounds into hydrocarbons over Mo2C catalyst. Although Stellwagen and Bitter [32] has researched the catalytic conversion of stearic acid over pre-treated carbon nanofibers (CNFs)-supported Mo2C, the yield of alkanes is relatively low of 80% at 300°C. In addition, the catalytic conversion of a mixture of long-chain fatty acid and amide compound in microalgae-based bio-oils over Mo2C catalyst has not been reported. Herein we describe for the first time that Mo2C/CNTs can efficiently catalyze the conversion of stearic acid and a mixture of stearic acid and nitrogen-containing compound to diesel-like hydrocarbons at a lower temperature (≤ 200°C). In this work, catalytic hydrotreatment of stearic acid and hexadecanamide as the oxygen-containing, nitrogen-containing model compound in microalgae-based bio-oils, respectively, was carried out over the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst, which was synthesized by the carbothermal hydrogen reduction (CHR) method. The aim of the present work is to evaluate catalytic performance of β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst in multi-aspect including HDO and hydrodenitrogeneration (HDN) process under mild conditions (≤200°C). Reaction parameters optimization and a brief pathway based on the experimental results had been investigated in the HDO process. This work will develop a foundation on industrial production of liquid hydrocarbons via hydrotreating process over inexpensive transition metal catalysts with the economic value and strategic significance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Stearic acid (98%), octadecane (≥99.5%), heptadecane (≥99.5%), hexadecane (≥99%), pentadecane (≥99%) and octadecanol (≥99.5%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Hexadecanamide was provided from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd., Decane (>99%) and ammonium molybdate (99.0%) were purchased by Guangfu Technology Development Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Multi-walled CNTs (>95%) were generously provided from XFNANO Materials Tech., Co., Ltd. (Nanjing, China). All reagents were used as-received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The β-Mo2C supported CNTs (BET specific surface area: 178m2 g−1) catalyst was synthesized by the CHR method described as follows: in a typical run, β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst was prepared by first dissolving ammonium molybdate (1.36g) in deionized water (15mL) and then slowly dropping this solution onto CNTs (2g) with continuously stirring in a 100mL beaker. After allowing the metal to permeate into the support for 12h at ambient temperature, the catalyst was first dried at 105°C for 3h. The dried sample was then calcined in air at 500°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1, and maintained at that temperature for 3h. Thereafter, it was disposed by reduction in a H2 flow of 80mLmin−1 from room temperature to 700°C with 10°Cmin−1 and reduced at 700°C for 4h. The theoretical β-Mo2C loading was approximately 5% based on CNTs support. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE diffractometer using copper radiation (Cu Kα λ =0.1541nm) at 36kV and 2mA, and the samples were analyzed by scanning at an angle ranging from 0° to 80° with a scan rate of 2°min−1. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution plot were measured in a Micromeritics Tristar analyzer at −196°C. Pretreatment of samples was done by flowing N2 for 3h at 300°C. The surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the pore size distribution was calculated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a PHI5300 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with a monochromatic X-ray source (Al Kα). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained by a FEI Tecnai F20 Field Emission Electron Microscope, and operated at an accelerating voltage of 200kV. At least 100 particles were counted to obtain the average diameter of β-Mo2C particles. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements The catalytic hydrogenation experiments of stearic acid and a mixture of stearic acid and hexadecanamide (5:1) were carried out in a batch autoclave. The autoclave was heated with an external electrical furnace, and the temperature was measured with a thermocouple and controlled at ±1°C. In a typical experiment, reactant (0.5g), decane (50mL), and catalyst (0.25g) were injected into the reactor, and then the autoclave was purged for three times with 0.2MPa H2 to remove air and pressurized with additional H2 to 4MPa at ambient temperature. The reaction temperature was increased to 180°C followed by a soak at 180°C for 4h at a stirring speed of 300rpm. The liquid samples were manually collected for analysis during the run and end of reaction. The catalyst was deposited at the bottom of the autoclave when the reaction was complete, and recovered for catalyst recycling by filtration and drying without further activation treatment. 2.5 Product analysis The final products of model compounds reaction were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Agilent GC6820) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) and a GsBP-Inowax capillary column (30m×0.32mm×0.25μm). The GC oven temperature was programmed as follows: 2min hold at 120°C, and then ramped to 260°C soaking for 10min at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. 2μL samples were injected into the column with a split ratio of 10:1, and the flow rate of carrier gas (helium) was 10mLmin−1. The injector and detector temperatures were maintained at 320°C and 280°C, respectively. Conversion was defined as mole% and calculated as moles of converted reactants (such as stearic acid, hexadecanamide) per moles of starting reactants times 100%. Yields were defined as mole% and calculated as moles of each product per mole of total product times 100%. Yield was calculated as conversion multiplied by the selectivity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 XRD analysis The XRD pattern (shown in Fig. 1 ) of the prepared catalyst shows that the diffraction peaks appear at 2θ of 34.3°, 38.0°, 39.4°, 52.1°, 61.5°, 69.6°,74.6° and 75.5°, which are assigned to the planes of (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (112) and (201) of the hexagonal close-packed β-Mo2C crystalline phase [33,34]. The diffraction peaks at 26.0° and 44.0° are contributed to CNTs with hexagonal structure. No other competing phases are detected, which indicates that the successful synthesis of β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst with well-crystallized structure proved by narrow and intensive diffraction peaks. 3.1.2 N2 adsorption–desorption analysis The typical N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst and corresponding BJH pore size distribution plot are shown in Fig. 2 . The shape of the sample isotherm exhibites representative type IV curves according to IUPAC recommendations [35], indicating that the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst is a typical mesoporous material with the presence of an H1-type hysteresis loop at relatively high pressures of 0.80–0.99 [Fig. 2(a)], which is usually associated with the open-ended capillary condensation that occurs in the mesopores [36]. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the sample possesses a large number of pores in the mesopore range, and larger pore size distribution centers at 25nm. The pore volume of β-Mo2C-supported catalysts is 0.5cm3 g−1, which may be related to the surface reconstruction of catalyst during preparation. Moreover, the typical BET surface area of β-Mo2C/CNTs is 116m2 g−1. 3.1.3 XPS analysis The XPS measurement was employed to identify the surface electronic state and chemical composition of the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. Fig. 3 (a) shows a typical survey XPS spectrum of the catalyst. The peaks of Mo (Mo 3d, 3p3/2, 3p1/2) and C (C 1s) in the survey XPS spectrum can be assigned to the characteristic of molybdenum carbides and CNTs. Meanwhile, the peak of O1s is attributed to the molybdenum oxides. Fig. 3(b) shows the high-resolution XPS spectrum for Mo 3d. The Mo 3d3/2 peak is centered at 232.1eV, whereas the Mo 3d5/2 peak is found at 228.9eV, with a spin energy separation of 3.2eV. This characteristic doublet of core-level Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 indicates the Mo (IV) oxidation state of MoO2. The characteristic peaks at 231.9 and 235.1eV can be attributed to Mo (VI) 3d5/2, 3d3/2, probably due to the slight oxidation of metastable MoO2 in air [37–39]. In addition, the peaks at 227.9eV and 231.3eV could be ascribed to Mo (II) 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 in β-Mo2C, respectively [32,40–42]. The content ratio of the Mo2+/(Mo4+ +Mo6+) on the surface of catalyst is 1.58, indicating the β-Mo2C is the main species on the surface of the catalyst, which is consistent with the XRD result. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum is deconvolved into four peaks corresponding to carbon atoms in different oxygen-containing functional groups. As can been seen from Fig. 3(c). The peak at 283.9eV is eligible for β-Mo2C, 284.8eV for CC, 285.8eV for CH, and 288.9eV for OCO, respectively [43–49]. Among them, the strongest peak of 283.9eV is assigned to β-Mo2C, and the others are relatively weak, suggesting the main phase of β-Mo2C on the surface of catalyst. The O 1s XPS signals of β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst can be fitted by three kinds of oxygen atoms locating at 530.3eV, 531.6eV and 532.7eV [Fig. 3(d)]. The peak at 530.3eV can be indexed as oxygen-containing group in the molybdenum oxides. The peaks at 531.6eV and 532.7 are assigned to OH and CO bonds, respectively [43,50]. 3.2 Deoxygenation of stearic acid over β-Mo2C/CNTs 3.2.1 The effect of reaction temperatures To study the influence of the reaction temperatures on the catalytic activity of the used catalyst and product distribution, the catalytic hydrogenation of stearic acid over β-Mo2C/CNTs at different temperatures was carried out. The results show that the conversion of stearic acid is only 68.39% at 160°C, but dramatically increases to 100% at 180°C. The product distribution results reveal that the highest yield for n-octodecane is up to 91.24% at the temperature of 180°C, as shown in Fig. 4 . There is no obvious difference on the yield of n-octadecane at the reaction temperature of 180°C and 190°C. When the temperature increases to 200°C, the yield of n-octadecane decreases to 86.28% because of the enhancement of heptadecane yield via decarbonylation. Large amounts of octadecanol can be achieved at a lower temperature (<180°C) during the process of catalytic hydrogenation, which indicates that the dehydration reaction of octadecanol to n-octodecane requires a higher temperature in the overall reaction when β-Mo2C/CNTs used as the catalyst. With the increase of reaction temperatures, the yield of n-heptadecane gradually increases, and the highest n-heptadecane yield of 13.72% is achieved at 200°C. This result suggests that higher temperatures favor the decarbonylation reaction of octadecanal to produce n-hepadecane over β-Mo2C/CNTs. By tracing the conversion course of stearic acid, intermediate octadecanal was confirmed. Because only traces of octadecanal were detected in the overall reaction, the octadecanal reduction rate to the octadecanol was proved to be faster than its production rate over β-Mo2C/CNTs. In addition, a blank test without catalyst was carried out to evaluate the contributions of the used catalyst at a reaction temperature of 200°C, and a very lower stearic acid conversion can be obtained. That is to say the presence of the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst plays a crucial role in the hydrogenation reaction of stearic acid. On the basic of the results mentioned above, 180°C is selected as the favorable reaction temperature in this paper. 3.2.2 The effect of reaction times In order to investigate the influence of reaction times on deoxygenation of stearic acid, the experiments of catalytic hydrogenation as the increase of reaction times were carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . The conversion of stearic acid and the yields of liquid hydrocarbons almost linearly increase with the reaction times. The major liquid product is n-octadecane with the highest yield of 91.24% and the stearic acid conversion of 100% after 3h, whereas the yield of n-heptadecane enhances slightly from 5.12 to 8.76%, which indicates that the hydrogenation–dehydration of octadecanol is the major reaction route during the deoxygenation process of stearic acid. The content of octadecanol is relatively stable in the overall reaction, and the yield declines sharply with almost complete conversion of stearic acid after 2.5h, which can been explained that the initial deoxygenation reaction proceeds firstly by a fast hydrogenation of the carboxylic group to octadecanol, and then the obtained octadecanol undergoes dehydration to produce the major product of n-octadecane over β-Mo2C/CNTs. Only traces of n-octadecene are detected during transformation of stearic acid, because of the fast hydrogenation of the double bond to n-octadecane over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. No other products are found in the deoxygenation process, such as esters or ketones, which indicates the good hydrodeoxygenation performance of β-Mo2C/CNTs. Gas products obtained over the β-Mo2C/CNTs were also analyzed, and the main oxygen-containing product is water. Trace amounts of CO2 and CH4 were also detected in the reaction system. To understand the deoxygenation step of stearic acid to alkanes better, the representative intermediate, octadecanol, was employed in a catalytic hydrogenation experiment over β-Mo2C/CNTs with the same reaction conditions mentioned in conversion of stearic acid. As shown in Fig. 6 , the yield of n-octadecane and the conversion of octadecanol increase obviously with reaction times, and the highest n-octadecane yield of 88.26% is obtained with the octadecanol conversion of 100% at 2.5h, which also supports the view that hydrogenation–dehydration of octadecanol is the major reaction path of deoxygenation of stearic acid. In addition, the equilibrium between the octadecanol and octadecanal exists in the fact that yields of individually produced n-heptadecane and n-octadecene increase linearly with reaction times. 3.2.3 The effect of hydrogen pressures The catalytic hydrogenation of stearic acid under various reaction pressures were investigated over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. The results indicate that initial hydrogen pressures have a significant effect on the conversion of stearic acid, and the conversion of stearic acid is proportional to the initial hydrogen pressure in the range of 0–1MPa. As shown in Fig. 7 , a complete conversion of stearic acid is obtained when the initial hydrogen pressure increases to 1MPa. With further increase of the hydrogen pressure to 4MPa, the yield of n-octadecane enhances obviously to 91.24%, whereas the n-heptadecane yield reduces from 36.77 to 8.76%. This is related to the fact that the higher hydrogen pressure shifts the equilibrium from octadecanal to octadecanol, and benefits the hydrogenation–dehydration route of octadecanol to n-octadecane, and thus, the yield of n-octadecane without carbon atom loss is enhanced, whereas the yield of n-heptadecane obtained from decarbonylation of octadecanal is suppressed [14]. This suggested that higher hydrogen pressures heavily favor the hydrogenation–dehydration pathway over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. 3.2.4 Deoxygenation pathway of stearic acid Based on the results above, the reaction pathway of stearic acid over β-Mo2C/CNTs is proposed (see Scheme 1 ). The reaction pathway proceeds through an initial hydrogenation of the carboxylic group on β-Mo2C surface to form octadecanal as an intermediate, and then the octadecanal either decomposes by decarbonylation to produce hydrocarbon with one carbon atom loss (minor route) or converts into octadecanol by hydrogenation, subsequently, the produced octadecanol undergoes sequential hydrogenation and dehydration to obtain the final product of n-octadecane without carbon atom loss (major route). In addition, the equilibrium between the aldehyde and alcohol exists in the overall reaction, which can be deeply influenced by the hydrogen pressure, and further affects the yields of n-heptadecane and n-octadecane. Further investigation of the mechanism and conditions of β-Mo2C/CNTs for deoxygenation of fatty acid is ongoing in our group. 3.2.5 Stability tests of β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst The stability of the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst was evaluated in this work, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . It is interesting to note that the catalyst can be recyclable up to seven runs without considerable variation in the catalytic performance. As can be seen from Fig. 8. The catalytic stability was gradually reduced with the increase of corresponding octadecanol after the seventh runs of catalyst, and no significant variation in the conversion of stearic acid was observed. It is related to the fact that the dehydration reaction of aliphatic alcohol requires a higher energy in the overall reaction [51]. On the whole, the β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst is quite stable and recyclable in the HDO of stearic acid under ambient reaction conditions. In order to investigate the reasons of β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst for gradually reduced stability, TEM analysis was carried out to investigate the surface morphology and particle size of fresh β-Mo2C/CNTs and that after the twelfth cycle (Fig. 9 a and b). As shown in Fig. 9a and b, agglomerations of a few of β-Mo2C particles are observed after twelfth recycling. This phenomenon reveals that long-term exposure of catalyst in reaction substrate of stearic acid may cause mutual adhesion of CNTs, which leads to change of the interaction between CNTs and β-Mo2C, and further influences the distribution and agglomeration of β-Mo2C particles. The average diameter of β-Mo2C nanoparticles approximately increases from ∼10.99 (fresh) to ∼16.17nm (after the twelfth cycle) according to statistical analysis. To further elaborate reduction of catalytic stability, the catalyst after the twelfth cycle was characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. 10 , the XRD patterns of β-Mo2C/CNTs show that the position and intensity of β-Mo2C peaks are nearly the identical to the fresh Mo2C/CNTs, but the diffraction peak of CNTs at 2θ of 26° widens after the catalytic recycling tests, these results suggest that the structural destruction of CNTs is the main reason for gradually reduced stability of β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. 3.3 Hydrotreatment of stearic acid and hexadecanamide over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst As mentioned above, the β-Mo2C/CNTs show the superior catalytic activity and stability in converting of stearic acid to produce liquid hydrocarbons. Whereas hexadecanamide is another important compound existed in microalgae-based bio-oils [13]. In order to investigate the catalytic hydrotreating of microalgae-based bio-oils over β-Mo2C/CNTs, the hexadecanamide was selected as the nitrogen-containing model compound in this study, mixed with stearic acid for catalytic hydrotreating at the same reaction conditions used in catalytic hydrogenation of pure stearic acid. The difference of carbon chain length between stearic acid and hexadecanamide is beneficial to analysis and calculation of products yields based on specific product ownership of two different models. The contents ratio of stearic acid and hexadecanamide are selected at 5:1 according to chemical compositions of real microalgae-based bio-oils prepared by our group, of which fatty acid has highest content of 57.72%, followed by hexadecanamide of 7.08% [13], and the results of catalytic hydrogenation of a mixture of stearic acid and hexadecanamide over β-Mo2C/CNTs are listed in Fig. 11 . The product compositions reveal that the yield of alkanes are very low at temperature of 160°C, but dramatically increase with temperature to 53.47% at 180°C. Further increasing the reaction temperature to 200°C, the highest yield for alkanes are almost up to 100%. This results show that stearic acid and hexadecanamide can be converted completely into n-C15–C18 alkanes over β-Mo2C/CNTs. Large amounts of alcohol can be observed in the liquid-phase products when performing the reaction at a lower temperature (≤180°C). This result indicates that dehydration of the alcohol requires a higher temperature in the overall reaction when β-Mo2C/CNTs used as the catalyst, which is consistent with the results of deoxygenation of stearic acid. Compared to the complete conversion of pure stearic acid to alkanes at 180°C, the n-octadecane yield decreases from 91.24% to 56.73% with n-heptadecane yield increasing from 8.76% to 19.85% in the co-hydroprocessing of hexadecanamide and stearic acid at 200°C, the remarkable variation on yields of n-octadecane and n-heptadecane may be related to the enhanced decarbonylation of octadecanal intermediate in presence of hexadecanamide over β-Mo2C/CNTs. In addition, the sum mass fraction of n-octadecane and n-heptadecane is five times less than the sum mass fraction of n-hexadecane and n-pentadecane corresponding to the contents of 5:1 for two models by quantitative transformation, which may be related to the cracking of stearic acid. However, no cracking existed in hydrodeoxygenation of pure stearic acid, which confirms that hexadecanamide can promote cracking of partial stearic acid. Finally, the fact that no any nitrogen-containing compounds in liquid-phase products is detected suggests the superior high catalytic denitrification performance of β-Mo2C/CNTs, and the nitrogen in bio-oil was removed as the form of ammonia in gas phase. To evaluate the contributions of β-Mo2C/CNTs on hydrotreatment of stearic acid and hexadecanamide, a blank experiment without catalyst was conducted at the temperature of 200°C. It is found that large amounts of stearic acid and hexadecanamide remain unreacted with no alkanes production after 4h. This result suggests that the presence of the β-Mo2C/CNTs plays a crucial role in the hydrogenation reaction of stearic acid and hexadecanamide. The yield ratio of hexadecanol and octadecanol intermediate increases obviously in blank experiment at 200°C compared with that at lower temperature (≤180°C), which indicates that hexadecanamide is easier to be converted than stearic acid at 200°C without catalyst. Further investigation of the catalytic performance of β-Mo2C/CNTs for hydrotreatment of microalgae-based bio-oils is on going in our group. 4 Conclusions In summary, a highly selective HDO and HDN approach of heteroatomic compounds in microalgae-based bio-oils to produce diesel-like hydrocarbons is provided over β-Mo2C/CNTs in the work. The catalyst was synthesized by CHR method, and tested in catalytic hydrogenation reaction of stearic acid and hexadecanamide. It is found that β-Mo2C/CNTs is a potential alternative catalyst to convert heteroatomic model compounds into n-C15–C18 alkanes under a mild condition (≤200°C) effectively. In the hydrotreating process of stearic acid, the β-Mo2C/CNTs favors the pathway of hydrogenation–dehydration–hydrogenation to produce n-octadecane with an optimal yield of 91.24%. The recycle tests demonstrate that the β-Mo2C/CNTs exhibited excellent stability, and can be reused for seven times consecutively without reduction of catalytic stability. When the cycle increases to the twelfth, the catalytic stability of β-Mo2C/CNTs is obviously decreased. The agglomerations of active component β-Mo2C due to structural destruction of CNTs under acidic condition, is the reason for reduction of catalytic stability. Based on the determined products, a brief reaction pathway is proposed. The obtained results above open a new possibility to upgrade microalgae-based bio-oils into high-grade transportation bio-fuels. coredata.dc:description: Hydrotreatment of heteroatomic model compounds in microalgae-based bio-oils into diesel-like hydrocarbons was carried out over carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-supported β-Mo2C catalyst with superior activity and selectivity under a mild condition (≤200°C). The results show that stearic acid and hexadecanamide can be completely converted into n-C15–C18 alkanes over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst. The β-Mo2C/CNTs favors the pathway of hydrogenation–dehydration–hydrogenation to produce n-octadecane with an optimal yield of 91.24% at a lower temperature of 180°C during hydrotreating process of stearic acid. The recycle tests demonstrate that the β-Mo2C/CNTs exhibits excellent stability, and can be reused for seven times consecutively without reduction of catalytic stability. Based on the determined products, a brief reaction pathway is proposed. Therefore, a novel approach to produce diesel-like hydrocarbons via catalytic hydrotreatment of microalgae-based bio-oils over β-Mo2C/CNTs is introduced, which provides a basic research as well as technical parameters for its further industrialization.
coredata.dc:title: Effective conversion of heteroatomic model compounds in microalgae-based bio-oils to hydrocarbons over β-Mo2C/CNTs catalyst
